body:
Going just by semver versions, 0.13.0 is a breaking update compared to 0.12.0 and as a result of that it would be impossible to override the dependency of wayland-client with 0.13.0 since it will be incompatible.

The only way forward if 0.12.0 truly does not build would be to patch wayland-client, which should not be a huge issue if there were no major breaking changes.

In an ideal world, a build failure would be resolved on a patch version which would automatically be pulled in. Unfortunately it doesn't look like nix releases patches.

Note that wayland-client has just been bumped to 0.23.1 including a bump of the nix dependency.

In theory that should resolve the problem once Alacritty is updated (which I will do later today). In the meantime feel free to test if this issue is resolved when editing the Cargo.toml yourself.
Thanks for the piece of advice. I tried to force-use the updated wayland client, but `glutin:0.20` is still stuck on `wayland-client:0.21.11` and I could not find an updated for this library ...
Oh yeah, if glutin is still a minor or major version behind, that does not help.

Note that currently winit is using 0.11 internally. Downgrading Alacritty's `nix` version to `0.11` would likely solve this issue too.

**Edit:** Turns out this doesn't work since winit actually uses 0.21 of wayland-client and unfortunately the nix dependency has been bumped to 0.12 without performing a major upgrade of winit.

issue.title: Fix BSD build failure
issue.body:
This updates all dependencies removing any reference to nix 0.12 which
prevents successful builds on OpenBSD.

Fixes #2244.

body:
Thanks to the cooperation of the wayland-client maintainer, we were able to backport the 0.13 update of nix to the currently used version of winit. This should resolve all build failures with nix on BSD.

Could you confirm that this works for you @xguerin? I've created a PR which updates our dependencies to the required version here:
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/pull/2247
Note that while the `nix` build failure has been fixed now, `winit` still has a build error on OpenBSD and requires a new release.
Thanks for the great response time üëç

issue.title: Test BSD on CI
issue.body:
As issues like https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/2244 indicate, testing on Linux and macOS is not sufficient to make sure that BSD works properly.

While BSD is very likely to be a minor platform compared to Linux/macOS, I still think that Alacritty could significantly improve the level of support without raising the effort much.

Part of this is to ensure that the latest version of Alacritty at least builds on OpenBSD or FreeBSD as a simple sanity-check. Unfortunately travis does not support BSD natively but I'd propose to add a docker-based FreeBSD build to the standard CI process which at least tests that all tests succeed on the stable Rust platform.

body:
No problem. Note that this issue also raises the interesting question of running CI for at least one of the popular BSDs.

I've created a new issue to track this that might be of interest:
https://github.com/jwilm/alacritty/issues/2248

issue.title: Fix build errors on BSD
issue.body:
This updates winit and glutin to the latest git versions instead of
relying on releases to fix a build failure on BSD.

Unfortunately the upstream version bumps might still take a bit and
there hasn't been any feedback with regards to a planned release date.

This also fixes a slight issue on Windows where selections would start
when focusing a window and a build failure with some Linux systems

Fixes #2243.
Fixes #2170.
Fixes #2244.

body: @xguerin I'd be interested in getting feedback on #2253. Does that PR fix the build issues for you?
Let me check. I'll let you know ASAP.
